Example

The figure shows the graphs of \(y=\sin x\) and \(y=\cos x\) for \({0\le x\le \dfrac{1}{2}\pi}\). The two graphs intersect at the point where \(x=\dfrac{1}{4}\pi\). Find the shaded area.


Solution

To find the shaded area we could calculate the area under the graph of \(y=\sin x\) for \(x\) between 0 and \(\dfrac{1}{4} \pi\), and subtract this from the area under the graph of \(y=\cos x\) between the same limits. Alternatively the two processes can be combined into one and we can write

shaded area \(\\={\displaystyle\int_0^{\pi/4}( \cos x - \sin x )\ \mathrm{d}x} \\= \bigg[ \sin x + \cos x\bigg]_0^{\pi/4} \\= \left(\sin \left(\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right) + \cos \left(\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right)\right) -\left( \sin 0 +\cos 0\right) \\= \left(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)-(0+1)\\=\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{2}}-1\\=\sqrt{2}-1\)
